e704523a73aa.name: Don’t Panic, Just Hire

postListMetadata.sectionHeader: people work for people first, and companies second.
people work for people first, and companies second.

paragraphs.text: Follow Backchannel: Facebook | Twitter
paragraphs.name: 67f7

paragraphs.text: It’s impossible to overestimate the significance of this move for Microsoft. CEO Satya Nadella is three years into a turnaround that few people believed possible. When he was promoted to CEO in February 2014, Microsoft was in a bad place. Six months earlier, the company had posted its first-ever quarterly loss. Steve Ballmer announced he would step down, but before leaving, he pushed through the acquisition of Nokia. It was a costly mistake. Microsoft ended up paying $7.9 billion for the Finnish cellphone maker, according to an April 2015 SEC filing; the company wrote off nearly the entire sum in the final quarter of 2015.
paragraphs.name: 2ad3

paragraphs.text: In an early analyst call, Nadella quoted philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche, telling listeners that Microsoft must have “courage in the face of reality.” Three years later, this courage is paying off. Microsoft has been profitable for the last four quarters, and in January, it surpassed analyst expectations, doubling its revenue from its cloud-computing offering, Azure. Its search engine, Bing, has a hold on one fifth of the search market (even more, if you add AOL and Yahoo search, which are powered by Bing). With the launch of Microsoft Teams, it has aimed squarely at competitor Slack. It’s well on its way to transforming into a company that sells services in the cloud. Meanwhile, it has put $35 billion toward R&D for ambitious projects such as its mixed reality headset, the HoloLens, attempting to establish itself as a company that can bring credible innovations to market.
paragraphs.name: b31a

paragraphs.text: In an early analyst call, Nadella quoted philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche, telling listeners that Microsoft must have “courage in the face of reality.” Three years later, this courage is paying off. Microsoft has been profitable for the last four quarters, and in January, it surpassed analyst expectations, doubling its revenue from its cloud-computing offering, Azure. Its search engine, Bing, has a hold on one fifth of the search market (even more, if you add AOL and Yahoo search, which are powered by Bing). With the launch of Microsoft Teams, it has aimed squarely at competitor Slack. It’s well on its way to transforming into a company that sells services in the cloud. Meanwhile, it has put $35 billion toward R&D for ambitious projects such as its mixed reality headset, the HoloLens, attempting to establish itself as a company that can bring credible innovations to market.
paragraphs.name: b31a

paragraphs.text: To succeed, however, Nadella must do more than fix the company’s business. He must turn around Microsoft’s lethargic, boastful, go-it-alone reputation — especially in clubby Silicon Valley where deals are made over dinners, the most talented entrepreneurs have their pick of big-name investors, and talent is hard to woo. In the constant competition over engineers, designers and product managers, Microsoft must establish itself as a smart place to do great work. In other words, in Silicon Valley it’s gotta be cool.
paragraphs.name: 12a9

paragraphs.text: Enter Reid Hoffman. Hoffman earned his credentials over two decades of startup building and nurturing. He started the very first social networking website, Socialnet.com, back in 1997 when Mark Zuckerberg was still in middle school. He met Facebook’s plucky founder before the kid dropped out of Harvard, and he helped broker the startup’s first $500,000 investment (kicking in $40,000 of his own). He was a founding board member at PayPal, and helped start LinkedIn back when most execs thought the idea of exposing your little black book was career suicide. LinkedIn now lays claim to more than 400 million members. In 2010, Hoffman joined venture firm Greylock, managing a seed fund that has invested in Groupon, Dropbox, Pandora, Tumblr, Shopkick, and Airbnb, where he’s a board observer. His list of for-profit and nonprofit board seats is lengthy.
paragraphs.name: 19ed

paragraphs.text: In an early analyst call, Nadella quoted philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche, telling listeners that Microsoft must have “courage in the face of reality.” Three years later, this courage is paying off. paragraphs.text: Paid 26B acquisition, wow! That’s something. Now, let’s see how they will roll the ball. Personally, LinkedIn is important to me because of my resume, people and my previous colleague found me through this social platform.

paragraphs.text: Microsoft are dead to me as a company. I use their products, with reluctance, and fully intend switching to Linux over time.

paragraphs.text: I dislike Windows 8, have vowed to NEVER use Windows 10 Spyware on any machine I own and will stick with Windows 7 as long as possible. After that, Linux.

paragraphs.text: I personally believe that this is a major factor that played a part in the acquisition. However, I also believe that the $26 billion paid by Microsoft will be integral to developing their service for professionals. I slightly disagree with the notion that the purchase was a cover up for an executive to be on the Microsoft board.

paragraphs.text: Which basically means the acquisition was to use it as a write off later. Microsoft’s benefit and wrangling necessary for positioning their own products and manipulating the telecom marketplace. Taking Nokia was a strategic move.

1d35496f1334.title: Buying LinkedIn in order to be perceived as “cool”, is kinda like the suburban white kid who tries…

paragraphs.text: Buying LinkedIn in order to be perceived as “cool”, is kinda like the suburban white kid who tries to act like he’s from the “hood” (especially when neither one was all that great to begin with).

paragraphs.text: Nice narrative. The power of network is definitely useful and cannot be overstated. But linking a $26BN acquisition to this is unconvincing. The heading of the article makes one believe that MS/Nadella spent billions to get a foot in the valley door. My 2 cents.
